source_caption_data.pre_caption: This video is a close-up scenery shot focused on two distinct textures. Initially, the frame is split, with a light tan, grid-patterned surface occupying the foreground on the left. To its right and in the middle ground is a dark, reddish-brown surface featuring a horizontal row of circular indentations. As the shot progresses, the tan surface on the left moves horizontally out of the frame, causing the reddish-brown surface to shift left and eventually fill the entire view. The camera maintains a level, straight-on angle relative to the surfaces throughout this transition.

Return only the one-paragraph video description without Markdown formatting or introductory text.

First, specify the **shot size** based on the subject's size in the frame if major subjects are present. If the shot size is unclear, describe how much of the subject is visible. If no major subject exists (e.g., a scenery shot), describe the shot size in relation to the scenery.

Next, describe the **spatial position of subjects and elements in the video**, if relevant. Indicate their approximate **2D position** within the frame using terms like **left, right, bottom left, bottom right, top right, top left, bottom, top, or center**. If **shot size or spatial position** changes, describe how these transitions occur clearly, specifying both the **initial and final states**.

In addition, the human-written captions below already describe the subjects (if any) and the scenery in this video but do not capture their spatial composition and movements. Use these captions as a reference, but do not rely on them completely. Your goal is to fully capture the spatial framing and movements in this video. The reddish-brown material extends behind the sandy-colored surface. As the video progresses, the sandy-colored surface on the left gradually moves out of the frame, allowing the reddish-brown material to occupy the entire frame.
